document.docTitle: Alpagut masakazui Yamada & Hayashi 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: First East Asian record of the genus Alpagut (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Dipsocoridae), with description of a new species and a note on the metacoxal adhesive pad of Dipsocoridae

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First East Asian record of the genus Alpagut (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Dipsocoridae), with description of a new species and a note on the metacoxal adhesive pad of Dipsocoridae

Description. Male.
Body oblong-oval, large (2.0– 2.68 mm ).

Coloration ( Figs. 1–6 , 19 ). Head light brown to chestnut-brown; eyes and ocelli dark red; antennae yellowishbrown; labium yellowish-brown. Pronotum light brown to chestnut-brown; posterior margin with a wide dark band; anterior margin sometimes with a narrow dark band. Scutellum light brown, paler along the scutellar margin. Forewing somewhat darker than the pronotum. Ventral surface of thorax uniformly smoky brown. Abdomen dark brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1‒6. Habitus of
Alpagut masakazui
sp. nov.
1–3, Holotype, male, dorsal (1), lateral (2), and ventral (3) views; 4–6, paratype, female, dorsal (4), lateral (5), and ventral (6) views. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 7‒15. Morphological details of
Alpagut masakazui
sp. nov. , male.
7–9, Abdomen, dorsal (7), ventral (8), and lat- eral (9) views; 10, left laterotergite 6 with an appendage, laterodorsal view; 11, left laterotergite 7, laterodorsal view; 12, tergite 8, dorsal view; 13–14, left paramere, two different aspects; 15, right paramere, dorsal view.Abbreviations: dag = dorsal abdomi- nal gland scars; app = apical process of paramere; bpp = basal process of paramere; lp = left paramere; lt2–8 = laterotergite 2 to 8; lt6ap = appendage of laterotergite 6; mt7–8 = mediotergite 7 to 8; mt8ap = appendage of mediotergite 8; py = pygophore; rp = right paramere; st7–8 = sternum 7 to 8. Scale bars = 0.2 mm for 7–9; 0.1 mm for 10–15.

FIGURES 16‒18. Morphological details of
Alpagut masakazui
sp. nov.
16, Female genital segments, dorsal view; 17, sper- matheca; 18, right forewing of male, dorsal view. Abbreviations: cf = costal fracture; clf = claval fracture; ct = cuticular thick- ening; d = spermathecal duct; g = spermathecal gland; ip = intermediate piece; le1 and le2 = lamellar expansion 1 and 2; sc = seminal capsule; t7–8 = tergite 7 to 8. Scale bars = 0.5 mm for 18; 0.1 mm for 16–17.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female ( Figs. 16–17 ). Similar to male in coloration, surface, and vestiture; tarsal formula 2-2-3; forewing usually surpassing apex of abdomen; abdomen superficially symmetrical in dorsal view; tergites 7 (t7) and 8 (t8) symmetrical, with cuticular thickenings (ct) on right and left sides of anterior and posterior margins and along lateral margin ( Fig. 16 ); left side of anterior margin of tergites 7 and 8 slightly thickened than right side from anterior view. Genitalia: spermatheca as shown in Figs. 16–17 ; loculus capsulae present; seminal capsule (sc) situated in the left side of the cavity, gently surrounded by two lamellar expansions; lamellar expansion 1 ( Fig. 16 : le1) derived from left side of posterior part of tergite 7; lamellar expansion 2 ( Fig. 16 : le2) from left side of anterior part of sternite 7, a little narrower than le1; the expansions weakly curved, not closely covering the seminal capsule; lamellar expansion also present on right side of anterior margin of sternite 7; seminal capsule spherical, large, (diameter approximately 0.1 mm ), turns into a caudal appendage on one side and forms a short canal leading to intermediate piece (ip) of the spermathecal duct (d) ( Fig. 17 ); intermediate piece extremely swollen as a large vesicular dilation on anterior part ( Fig. 17 ); spermathecal gland (g) fused near a caudal appendage of seminal capsule, slender, bulbous at apex ( Fig. 17 ).

Measurements. Males (n = 10, holotype in parentheses). Body length 2.00–2.68 (2.35); head width across eyes 0.42–0.47; interocular distance 0.27–0.31; length of antennal segments I – 0.08–0.09 (0.09), II – 0.18–0.22 (0.19), III – 0.51–0.55 (0.55), and IV – 0.39–0.48 (0.42); length of labial segments II – 0.10–0.14 (0.13), III – 0.14–0.17 (0.17), and IV – 0.11–0.14 (0.14); length of pronotum along meson 0.28–0.34 (0.31); width of pronotum 0.59–0.79 (0.66); length of forewing 1.55–2.10 (1.80); length of hind tibiae 0.61–0.80 (0.68).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 19‒22. Living individuals and habitats of
Alpagut masakazui
sp. nov.
19, Specimen from Inomegawa Riv., Izumo-shi, Shimane Pref. (sex unidentified); 20, specimen from Hiikawa Riv., Unnan-shi, Shimane Pref., in the water (sex unidentified); 21–22, habitat, Hiikawa Riv., Unnan-shi, Shimane Pref. The arrow shows the collecting site (the wet moss on the stone in the channel of the river)—all photographs by Masakazu Hayashi, published with permission.

subSubSection.paragraph: Females (n = 10). Body length 1.93–2.40; head width across eyes 0.42–0.47; interocular distance 0.27–0.31; length of antennal segments I – 0.08–0.10, II – 0.16–0.20, III – 0.43–0.53, and IV – 0.33–0.41; length of labial seg- ments II – 0.09–0.14, III – 0.15–0.18, and IV – 0.11–0.13; length of pronotum along meson 0.28–0.32; width of pronotum 0.58–0.78; length of forewing 1.45–1.90; length of hind tibiae 0.61–0.75.

Etymology. It was named after Dr. Masakazu Hayashi who collected valuable specimens herein designated as type series and provided useful biological information and explicit photographs of this new species.

Bionomics. Most specimens of this species were collected under stones along the bank of the river in the low mountain area ( Figs. 21–22 ) and sometimes found together with
Cryptostemma miyamotoi Yamada & Hayashi, 2019
and
Pachycoleus japonicus (Miyamoto, 1964) ( Yamada & Hayashi 2019 )
. In the Hiigawa River, Shimane Prefecture , some individuals were also found from wet moss on stones in the channel of the river ( Fig. 22 ). In the laboratory observation, one individual of this species entered the water along moss on the stone (Masakazu Hayashi pers. comm. ). Fine air bubbles enveloped on its body surface in the water ( Fig. 20 ). This evidence suggests the possible existence of a plastron for respiration in this species. As indicated by Štys (1990) , when individuals are submerged, a plastron film that may combine with a large air bubble develops immediately over their bodies.
